issues.text: Whether the petitioners cannot be tried for the offences in question by reason of cl. 2 of Art. 20 of the Constitution and s. 403 of the Code of Criminal Procedure

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of both the petitioners the contention is that by reason of cl. 2 of Art. 20 of the Constitution and s. 403 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, the petitioners cannot be tried for the offences in question.

issues.text: Whether the first trial without sanction was by a Court of competent jurisdiction so as to attract the bar under s. 403(1) CrPC

anchor.surface_text: the whole basis of s. 403(1) was that the first trial should have been before a Court competent to hear and determine the case and to record a verdict of conviction or acquittal

issues.text: Whether ss. 190, 191, 192, 529 and 530 CrPC draw a distinction between taking cognizance and jurisdiction that permits trial without sanction under s. 6 Prevention of Corruption Act

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the petitioners invited our attention to ss. 190, 191, 192, 529 and 530 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and submitted that in certain circumstances the Code drew a distinction between jurisdiction and taking cognizance.

issues.text: Whether cl. 2 of Art. 20 applies where earlier proceedings were null and void

arguments.claim: By reason of cl. 2 of Art. 20 of the Constitution and s. 403 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, the petitioners cannot be tried for the offences in question.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of both the petitioners the contention is that by reason of cl. 2 of Art. 20 of the Constitution and s. 403 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, the petitioners cannot be tried for the offences in question.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: taking companynizance and jurisdiction. The distinction was drawn in a case where a Magistrate duly empowered to companymit cases to the Sessions Cou

arguments.court_reasoning: Earlier proceedings null and void; petitioners not prosecuted/punished more than once under Art. 20(2); not tried by competent court with conviction/acquittal in force under s. 403 CrPC.

arguments.claim: The Code of Criminal Procedure draws a distinction between taking cognizance of an offence and jurisdiction to try, permitting trial despite lack of sanction.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the petitioners invited our attention to ss. 190, 191, 192, 529 and 530 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and submitted that in certain circumstances the Code drew a distinction between jurisdiction and taking cognizance. The whole fabric of the argument of learned counsel was founded on this distinction.

arguments.court_reasoning: Mandatory provisions of s. 6 Prevention of Corruption Act prevent any court from taking cognizance without sanction, rendering court incompetent; ss. 529 and 530 do not apply and s. 530 voids such proceedings.

arguments.claim: The Privy Council decision in Yusofalli Mulla v. The King is wrong and the decision of this Court in Budha Mal v. State of Delhi requires reconsideration.

anchor.surface_text: we have heard learned counsel for the petitioners who made a vain attempt with a crusading pertinacity worthy of a better cause, to show that the Privy Council decision was wrong and the decision of this Court required reconsideration, and having heard learned counsel in full,

arguments.court_reasoning: Decisions state the legal position correctly after full hearing.

arguments.claim: The point is concluded by binding precedents: Yusofalli Mulla v. The King (Privy Council), Basdeo Agarwalla v. King-Emperor (Federal Court), and Budha Mal v. State of Delhi (this Court).

anchor.surface_text: Now, it is necessary to state that the point taken by learned counsel for the petitioners is really concluded by three decisions- (a) one of the Privy Council, (b) another of the Federal Court and (c) the third of this Court itself. The Privy Council decision is in Yusofalli Mulla v. The King the Federal Court decision in Basdeo Agarwalla v. King-

arguments.claim: Absence of previous sanction under s. 6 of Prevention of Corruption Act renders court without jurisdiction to take cognizance, making trial a nullity not attracting s. 403 CrPC bar.

anchor.surface_text: the whole basis of s. 403(1) was that the first trial should have been before a Court competent to hear and determine the case and to record a verdict of conviction or acquittal if the Court was not so competent, as for example where the required sanction for the prosecution was not obtained,

arguments.claim: Cl. 2 of Art. 20 has no application as petitioners are not being prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once; earlier proceedings held null and void.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear beyond any doubt that cl. 2 of Art. 20 of the Constitution has no application in these two cases. The petitioners are not being prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once,

arguments.claim: S. 403 CrPC does not bar retrial as petitioners were not tried by a court of competent jurisdiction in earlier proceedings and no conviction or acquittal remains in force.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to s. 403, Code of Criminal Procedure, it is enough to state that the petitioners were not tried, in the earlier proceedings, by a Court of competent jurisdiction, nor is there any conviction or acquittal in force within the meaning of s. 403(1) of the Code,

arguments.claim: S. 530 CrPC provides that proceedings by magistrate not empowered by law to try offender shall be void, supporting that lack of sanction voids trial.
S. 529(e) CrPC exception for taking cognizance under s. 190(1)(a)(b) has no bearing where sanction under s. 6 PCA is mandatory and absent.
Distinction between taking cognizance and jurisdiction in Basdeo v. Emperor (Allahabad HC) not applicable to cases involving mandatory sanction under s. 6 PCA.
arguments.court_reasoning: Facts different; no occasion to consider mandatory sanction provisions.

holdings.text: cl. 2 of Art. 20 of the Constitution has no application in these two cases. The petitioners are not being prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once, the earlier proceedings having been held to be null and void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Earlier proceedings held null and void ab initio due to absence of valid sanction; no prosecution and punishment more than once.

holdings.text: the petitioners were not tried, in the earlier proceedings, by a Court of competent jurisdiction, nor is there any conviction or acquittal in force within the meaning of s. 403(1) of the Code, to stand as a bar against their trial for the same offences.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to s. 403, Code of Criminal Procedure, it is enough to state that the petitioners were number tried,- in the earlier proceedings, by a Co

holdings.reasoning_summary: First trial invalid due to lack of sanction; court lacked jurisdiction; no effective conviction or acquittal remains.

holdings.text: the decisions referred to above state the legal position correctly.

anchor.surface_text: we are of the view that the decisions referred to above state the legal position companyrectly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms Privy Council (Yusofalli Mulla), Federal Court (Basdeo Agarwalla), and this Court (Budha Mal) that trial without sanction is by incompetent court, not barring retrial under s.403.

holdings.text: If noCourt can take cognizance of the offences in question without a legal sanction, it is obvious that noCourt can be said to be a Court of competent jurisdiction to try those offences and that any trial in the absence of such sanction must be null and void

anchor.surface_text: Assuming, however, that in certain cases one Magistrate may take cognizance and another Magistrate may try an accused person, it is difficult to appreciate how any Court can try the petitioners

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandatory requirement of s.6 Prevention of Corruption Act deprives court of jurisdiction to take cognizance without sanction; trial nullity.

holdings.text: Section 530 of the Code is really against the contention of learned counsel, for it states, inter alia, that if any Magistrate not being empowered by law to try all offender, tries him, then the proceedings shall be void.

anchor.surface_text: Section 530 of the Code is really against the companytention of learned companynsel, for it states, inter alia, that if any Magistrate number being empowered by law to try all offender, tries him, then the proceedings shall be void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of sanction means magistrate not empowered; proceedings void under s.530 CrPC.

holdings.text: Section 529(e) is merely an exception in the matter of taking cognizance of an offence under s. 190, sub-s. (1), cls. (a) and (b) it has no bearing in a case where sanction is necessary and no sanction in accordance with law has been obtained.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.529(e) exception limited to cognizance under s.190(1)(a)(b); inapplicable where mandatory sanction under s.6 PCA absent.

holdings.text: The facts there were entirely different from the facts of the present cases and there was no occasion no necessity for considering such mandatory provisions as are contained in s. 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction in Basdeo v. Emperor (Allahabad HC) on cognizance vs jurisdiction not applicable to mandatory sanction cases under s.6 PCA.

anchor.surface_text: Budha Mal v. State of Delhi  3  on October 3, 1952. The Privy Council decision is directly in point, and it was there held that the whole basis of s. 403  1  was that the first trial should have been before a Court companypetent to hear and determine the case and to record a verdict of companyviction or acquittal if the Court was number so companypetent, as for example where the required sanction for the prosecution was number obtained, it was irrelevant that it was companypetent to try other cases of the same class or indeed the case against the particular accused in different circumstances, for example if a sanction had been obtained. So is the decision of this Court where the following observations were made with regard to the point in question Section 403, Criminal Procedure Code, applies to cases where the acquittal order has been made by a Court of companypetent jurisdiction but it does number bar a retrial of the accused in cases where such an order has been made by a companyrt which had numberjurisdiction to take companynizance of the case.

precedents.cited_proposition: Section 403, Criminal Procedure Code, applies to cases where the acquittal order has been made by a Court of competent jurisdiction but it does not bar a retrial of the accused in cases where such an order has been made by a court which had no jurisdiction to take cognizance of the case
precedents.cited_holding: Section 403, Criminal Procedure Code, applies to cases where the acquittal order has been made by a Court of companypetent jurisdiction but it does number bar a retrial of the accused in cases where such an order has been made by a companyrt which had numberjurisdiction to take companynizance of the case.

anchor.surface_text: Basdeo v. Emperor  1 , where the learned Judge drew a distinction between taking companynizance and jurisdiction. The distinction was drawn in a case where a Magistrate duly empowered to companymit cases to the Sessions Court companymitted ail accused person to the Court of Session in disregard of the provisions of s. 254 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, and the question was whether the irregularity so companymitted rendered the Sessions Court incompetent to try the case. The facts there were entirely different from the facts of the present cases and there was numberoccasion number necessity for companysidering such mandatory provisions as are companytained in s. 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act. We do number think that the observations made in that case can be pressed in service in support of the argument of learned companynsel for the petitioners in these cases, treating those observations as though they laid down any abstract propositions of law number dependent on the companytext of the facts in companynection with which they were made.
